name: C++ Deque
description: C++ <deque> is an indexed sequence container that allows fast insertion and deletion at both its beginning and its end

Iterators.val: Returns an iterator pointing to the first element in the deque container
Returns an iterator referring to the past-the-end element in the deque container
Returns a reverse iterator pointing to the last element in the container
Returns a reverse iterator pointing to the theoretical element preceding the first element in the deque container
Returns a const_iterator pointing to the first element in the container (C++ 11 only)
Returns a const_iterator pointing to the past-the-end element in the container (C++11 only)
Returns a const_reverse_iterator pointing to the last element in the container (C++11 only)
Returns a const_reverse_iterator pointing to the theoretical element preceding the first element in the container (C++11 only)

Capacity.val: Returns the number of elements in the deque container
Returns the maximum number of elements that the deque container can hold
Resizes the container so that it contains n elements
Returns whether the deque container is empty
Requests the container to reduce its memory usage to fit its size

Element Access.val: Returns a reference to the element at position n in the deque container
Returns a reference to the element at position n in the array
Returns a reference to the first element in the array container
Returns a reference to the last element in the array container
Returns a pointer to the first element in the array object

Modifiers.val: Sets val as the value for all the elements in the array object
Exchanges the content of the array by the content of x, which is another array object of the same type

Allocator.val: Returns a reference to the ith element of array arr
Performs the appropriate comparison operation between the array containers lhs and rhs

Function Overloads.val: Accesses the static type of the elements in an array object as if it was a tuple
Provides access to the number of elements in an std::array as a compile-time constant expression
